articles.title: Authentic Assessment
articles.contents:
During 2020-2021 academic year I participated in a Faculty Learning Community on Authentic Assessment. We explored definition, current practices around authentic assessment and produced the following artifacts.
Final Presentation
This presentation summarises the findings on the group’s research and discussion on authentic assessment.
Where do I start
This document provides tips and suggestions to incorporating authentic assessment in your course
Initial Faculty Survey Results
The research subgroup conducted survey among the SJSU faculty. This dashboard summarises early results we have observed. The response rate is less than 2% at this time. We plan to revisit the survey later in the summer. The survey follows the IRB protocols and was approved prior to dissemination.

articles.title: About me
articles.contents:
About me
Shilpa has 10+ years of experience as a data scientist in various companies in the San Francisco / Bay Area where she has solved some hard business problems, done innovative work and delivered customer-impacting solutions. Currently she is an Adjunct Professor of Industrial and Systems Engineering at San Jose State University. She is passionate about statistics / data science pedagogy and volunteers her time mentoring middle/high school girls through More Active Girls In Computing and AI4ALL. She holds a doctorate in Industrial Engineering (Applied Statistics with minor in Optimization).
Shilpa is a certified Mental Health First Aider.
Teaching
coming soon

articles.title: ISE 194
articles.contents:
Welcome to the course ISE 194 Analytics Workshop website!
With explosion in the amount of data and computing capability, it has become imperative to have skills to turn that pieces of information into knowledge to make impactful decisions. In this course we will learn basics of data loading, wrangling, visualizing and analysis using R and Python for variety of real- world data. We will be only scratching the surface but my hope is that is enough to ignite your curiosity and drive to go forth and make impactful contributions to our society using these skills.
Why both R and Python
Being multilingual is good for cognition and job marketability
Both are open source with active communities
General Purpose vs {Build by and for Statisticians}
Data Munging speed vs {ease of exploratory data analysis + statistical analysis + data visualization} (Note: though the gap is closing between the two rapidly)
R in python code → Rpy2 and Python in R code → reticulate
IDEs used
Jupyter Notebook via Anaconda distribution
RStudio
Libraries covered
Python
numpy, pandas, matplotlib, dash, sqlite3
In limited capacity: statsmodel, scipy
R
tidyverse, lubridate, ggplot2, rmarkdown, flexdashboard, sqlite, reticulate
Additional
git and github
deploy flexdashboard on shinyapps.io
Service Learning
ISE 194 Analytics Workshop course offered by the SJSU’s Industrial and Systems Engineering to its seniors was developed for students to learn problem solving using common programming languages. This course focuses on learning the syntax of common analytics programming languages and application to problems in industrial engineering, especially involving data to transform, analyze and visualize data to inform decisions. In Fall 2022, the course objective was expanded to include a service learning component with the belief that the skills learnt in the course to transform, analyze and visualize data were transferable to data collected by government and non-profit community organizations. This change was done on the belief that using our skills to create and sustain thriving communities is a hallmark of an engaged and active citizenry.
In order to use data analysis skills for civic engagement, the students worked on data provided by the Direct Discharge Trash Control Program housed in the San Jose Environmental Services Division. During the semester, the students used their analytics skills and new data programming skills to perform analysis on the data provided and produced an analysis report as well as a dashboard on the trash collected from encampments in the years 2020-2022 in and around the San Jose area. The students then wrapped up the semester by reflecting on their experience working with “real world” dataset.
Fall 2022 Service Learning Showcase

articles.title: ISE 201
articles.contents:
Welcome to the course ISE 201 Math Foundations for Data Science website!
It is a re-imagined ISE 201 with inclusion of Linear Algebra in addition to Probability and Statistics. Linear algebra and matrix operations have increasingly become pervasive with explosion in the amount of data and increase in computing capability in solving mathematical decision problems. In this course we cover concepts from linear algebra, probability, statistics and optimization techniques important for decision and data sciences, with motivation from real-world examples.
More Details Coming Soon!
In the meantime you can go through these tutorials (in beta)
R Introduction
Regression Tutorial
Student Projects
Link | Link |
Link
Link

articles.title: ISE 202
articles.contents:
Welcome to the course ISE 202 Design and Analysis of Engineering Experiments website!
Review of statistical inference and tests of hypotheses. Introduction to analysis of variance and covariance. Theory and applications of experimental designs for engineering problems. Random and systematic designs. Randomized blocks. Latin squares. Factorial and fractional factorial designs. Taguchi methods. Prerequisite: ISE 130.
Chapter 7 Examples
Chapter 8 Examples
More Details Coming Soon!

articles.title: ISE 244
articles.contents:
Welcome to the course ISE 244 AI Tools and Practice for Systems Engineering website!
This course focuses on Artificial Intelligence software tools useful for industrial and systems engineering. It emphasizes clear understanding of the mathematics behind them, what tools to use in which conditions, and how to interpret and use the results. Prerequisite: Graduate standing; ISE 201 (or Equivalent) or instructor consent. 3 Units.
SP22 Showcase

articles.title: More Active Girls In Computing
articles.contents:
One of my passion project outside of work is volunteering with More Active Girls In Computing to encourage middle and high school girls to pursue STEM careers by 1:1 mentoring on a hands-on project by a female role model.
We are always looking for mentors.
If you are interested and want to know more, please book a time on my calendar by clicking the link below.
Book time on Shilpa’s calendar

articles.title: Mental Health Resources
articles.contents:
“It’s OK to not be OK”
I am trained as a Mental Health First Aid. I am not a substitute for a licensed counselor. I can listen without judgment and connect you with helpful resources to promote your health and success. You can email me or find a time on my calendar
Mental Health Resources

articles.contents: During 2021-2022 academic year I participated in a Faculty Learning Community on Apprenticing Students into STEM Thinking. Will add details from the learning community in the coming months

articles.title: Knowing your Learners
articles.contents:
As part of the SJSU Resilient Course Design program, I contributed some approaches to understand the learners in our class better and some strategies for how do they learn best. This was open to all SJSU faculty during Summer 2021 and Winter 2021. Here are some artifacts created during that process.
Intro | Knowing your Learner | Start of Semester Survey | Midpoint reflection template | Learner Personas | Slides



You can view the whole course here
